p: It appears that knowledge on the causes of climate change may have varied effects on different health professionals. In this study, we found that the knowledge on the causes of climate change has no significant associations with perceived impacts of climate change in public health students. However, it is a significant predictor of perceived negative impacts of climate change in medical students, as is consistent with findings of a study on the general public across six countries [ 19]. Since different health professionals play a different role in climate change actions, some researchers have called for developing different approaches, such as teaching, learning, and assessment approaches in integrating climate change topics into the teaching curricula for medical, nursing, and public health students [ 27, 48, 49].
